awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven Elastic Shape Analysis with Topological Inconsistencies and Partial Matching Constraints
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project focuses on data structures that are represented as curves or surfaces. Such structures occur in applications ranging from brain anatomy, computer vision, and molecular biology to meteorological and financial data. Data can be either directly acquired by devices such as laser scans or indirectly reconstructed from microscopy or magnetic resonance imaging. Such images and analyses appear for example in the study of human anatomy and motion or in applications to computer graphics and motion. The project lies in the broad area of statistical shape analysis, in which one tries to quantify geometric and/or topological variability within and across populations. The work aims to develop practical methods to characterize the shape of data objects in order to ascertain their roles in larger systems. The project will involve graduate students and produce open source software. 

The project relies on the paradigms of elastic shape analysis, which is traditionally concerned with analyzing the variability in the geometries of the objects under consideration. At its core is the notion of a distance between two shapes, which stems from a Riemannian setting using a metric that is invariant to the action of certain shape-preserving transformations and embeds both the global nonlinearity of the space as well as its local linearity. The first goal is to develop a comprehensive theoretical and numerical framework for elastic shape analysis of curves and surfaces that allows for topological inconsistencies and partial matching constraints. This framework combines elastic shape analysis with methods from geometric measure theory and topological data analysis. The second goal is to apply the framework to a wide variety of synthetic and real data, in particular to morphological analysis of high-resolution orthopedic surface complexes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The past years have displayed a remarkable period of transition and growth in data-driven methodologies. This revolution is fueled by tremendous advances in data collection, storage and computation, which in turn results in newer, bigger and more complex datasets. As a consequence there is a need for researchers, in applications ranging from brain anatomy, computer vision and molecular biology to meteorological and financial data,  to characterize the shape of data objects in order to ascertain their roles in larger systems. One type of data that is of particular importance in this context and which is the main focus of the proposed research consists of data structures that are represented as curves or surfaces. These can be either directly acquired by devices such as laser scans or indirectly segmented/reconstructed from 2D or 3D images such as MRI, CT or microscopy. They constantly appear for example in the study of (human) organs in computational anatomy or in applications to computer graphics and motion analysis. 

The field of  statistical shape analysis in which one tries to quantify geometric and/or topological variability within and across populations has been the focus of intense research  in recent decades. In particular, the area of geometric shape analysis, in which the objects of interest are restricted to a certain topology, is concerned with analyzing the variability in their geometries.  
Despite the success of geometric shape analysis approaches in many applications, the assumption of consistent topology proves to be a severe limitation for the treatment of real data, where imaging noise and incomplete observations routinely lead to topological inconsistencies such as holes, missing parts or artifacts. The main goal of this project was to extend the theoretical and numerical setting of elastic shape analysis, that introduces metrics between shapes via elastic transformations, to deal with such additional non-elastic variability in curves and surfaces.

Towards this aim the research team developed  a comprehensive theoretical and numerical framework for elastic shape analysis of surfaces, that in addition allows for topological inconsistencies and partial matching constraints; In the final phase of the project the research team further  showcased the versatility and unique features of the developed framework on a wide variety of synthetic and real data, cf. the included Figure for several examples of optimal deformations between varying types of data.  In particular, and in collaboration with researchers from the University of Lille, applications to the study of human body shapes have been considered.  

The intellectual merit of the obtained results is further emphasized as they stand at the focal point of recent theoretical results and the need for new differential geometric and statistical tools in shape analysis. Thereby the project’s research simultaneously advanced the foundational study of infinite-dimensional shape spaces and their mathematical properties as well as led to novel, efficient and versatile numerical frameworks for the analysis of large real datasets of curves and surfaces. This is further exemplified by the wide range of outlets and communities where the project's findings have been shared, encompassing prominent applied mathematics and computer science journals like the International Journal of Computer Vision and the SIAM Journal on Imaging Sciences, as well as prestigious theoretical mathematics journals such as the Journal of the European Mathematical Society and Mathematische Annalen. As a consequence one can expect that the results of the proposed research will have future implications all the way from theory of infinite-dimensional spaces to the applications in 3D shape analysis, medical imaging and functional data analysis.

Beyond these research achievements the project impacted  the training of graduate student across several institutions. At FSU the project supported E. Hartman, who has successfully defended his Ph.D in spring 2024 and is now pursuing postdoctoral studies in the group of Prof Charon and at JHU the project supported Y. Sukurdeep, who graduated from his Ph.D in March 2023 and subsequently pursued a postdoc in a different research group at JHU. Another international masters student (Thomas Pierron) spent 9 months across the two institutions (FSU and JHU) for his internship and has subsequently started his Ph.D at ENS Paris-Saclay in the same field. An important aspect of the training of the involved students was the joint use of differential geometry, functional analysis and computational statistics in high-dimensional data analysis. Consequently the students trained under this project  possess enhanced skills to handle invariance, nonlinearity, variability, and high-dimensionality that is typical of datasets in current and future technologies and will prepare them well for future tasks in research and industry. Finally, the two PIs (Bauer and Charon) organized a retreat workshop "Maths in the Appalachians" during the Summer 2024 in which they put specific effort to extend invitations to early career researchers as a way to provide valuable experience and connections with researchers in the field.
